column3: C# is a programming language developed by Microsoft for building Windows applications
column5: and more. It is part of the .NET framework.

column2: What is the difference between value types and reference types in C#?
column4: whereas reference types store a reference to the data. Value types are stored on the stack
column5: and reference types are stored on the heap.

column2: Explain the concept of inheritance in C#.
column3: Inheritance is a mechanism in C# that allows a class to inherit properties and behavior from another class. It promotes code reusability and establishes a relationship between parent and child classes.

column2: What is the purpose of the 'using' statement in C#?
column3: The 'using' statement in C# is used to include a namespace in the program. It ensures that the resources are automatically released when the program execution exits the 'using' block.

column2: What is the difference between '== ' and 'Equals()' in C#?
column3: The '==' operator is used to compare the values of two variables
column4: while the 'Equals()' method is a method provided by the Object class for comparing object equality. The 'Equals()' method can be overridden in derived classes to provide custom comparison logic.

column2: What is the purpose of the 'async' and 'await' keywords in C#?
column3: The 'async' and 'await' keywords are used for asynchronous programming in C#. 'async' is used to declare an asynchronous method
column4: and 'await' is used to pause the execution until the awaited task completes.

column2: Explain the concept of delegates in C#.
column3: Delegates are a type-safe function pointer in C#. They are used to define and reference methods as objects
column4: allowing for greater flexibility in defining callback methods and event handling.

column2: What is LINQ (Language Integrated Query) in C#?
column3: LINQ is a feature in C# that allows developers to query data from different data sources using a SQL-like syntax. It provides a consistent way to query and manipulate data from arrays

column2: How does exception handling work in C#?
column3: Exception handling in C# is done using try
column6: and throw keywords. Code that might throw an exception is enclosed in a 'try' block
column7: and corresponding exception-handling code is written in the 'catch' block. The 'finally' block is executed whether an exception is thrown or not.

column2: What is the difference between 'var' and 'dynamic' in C#?
column3: 'var' is used for implicitly typed local variables
column4: and the type is determined at compile time. 'dynamic' is a type introduced in C# 4.0 that represents a dynamic type
column5: and its type is resolved at runtime. It provides more flexibility but lacks compile-time checking.
